PM11:09am

Just an observation, without being able to offer an explanation, but we note the following

The UK Short Sterling (interest rate) futures is under some renewed pressure this morning, as the curve continues to steepen, despite the consensus view suggesting that assuming that the BoE does hike rates in November, it may well be a case of ‘one and done’

PM11:09am

2) Notably, one of the typical bellwethers for money market tensions, the LIBOR/OIS spread has inverted as markets have moved to discount a November move, with secured rates (OIS) edging above unsecured (LIBOR), a premium which is understandable given the lack of clarity about the short to medium term GBP rate trajectory.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

There ya go -- old fashioned money market tensions

PM11:10am

3) Though it may be the case that this is in part Cross Currency Basis swap related, in so far as the equivalent USD rates & spread have been largely static…

PM11:10am

… certainly one to keep an eye on!

NEX Group PLC (NXG:LSE): Last: 657.50, down 3.5 (-0.53%), High: 659.00, Low: 652.00, Volume: 127.75k
11:18 am
PM11:18am

Jenny Knott off

PM11:18am

She headed this division that brought us a profit warning last month

PM11:19am

Shore are pretty scathing on all this

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Paul McGinnis

PM11:19am

Let me get is reiterated Sell

PM11:19am

NEX Group has announced this morning that Jenny Knott will be stepping down as CEO of the Group’s Optimisation Division (which represented 44% of Mar ’17 continuing Group revenue and 37% of continuing operating profit before group costs). She will be replaced by Ken Pigaga, current Group COO, a role that will now be filled by recently appointed CFO Sam Wren alongside her existing responsibilities.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

It is just two weeks since Ms Knott hosted an investor teach-in on NEX Optimisation, an event that slightly embarrassingly was held against a backdrop of a profit warning from that division. Operating margins for the six months to 30th September were guided at 20% compared to 28% in the year ended May ’17 (and a heroic-looking Mar ’20 target of 40%). We were slightly bemused at the fact that this was communicated as being the result of decisions to invest in transforming the division to a more client-centric culture and on MiFID II related marketing. If this was the case, why wait until after the period has ended before announcing it ?

PM11:20am

Ken Pigaga was originally earmarked to join TP ICAP^ (TCAP, Sell at 536p) when NEX sold its voice broking division to the former Tullett Prebon, but ultimately elected to decline that position and stayed at NEX Group.

Following that profit warning, we cut our Mar ’18 adjusted eps by 15% and by 5% for the following two years, summarised in a short note entitled ‘Taking too much on trust’. However, much to our bewilderment, a gravity-defying share price has now largely recovered the c10% fall seen on the day of the warning. At Friday’s closing price of 661p, NEX trades on 28.6x our Mar ’18 adjusted eps of 23.1p, falling to 19.7x in Mar ’19 (which gives credit for a margin recovery at Optimisation).

Our fair value of 465p is 30% below the current shares price and is set on a standalone basis. To us, investors hanging in there for a takeover from a large exchange should be cognisant of the fact that the takeover premium may well already be in the share price. Another profit warning certainly is not. SELL

PM11:20am

The rating is eye-watering, no?

PM11:21am

PM11:27am

The supply issues principally relate to the movement of Advanced Wound Care manufacturing lines from Greensboro in the U.S. to Haina in the Dominican Republic, including delays in obtaining regulatory certification, as well as the movement of the final two Ostomy manufacturing lines. The costs associated with these supply issues are expected to result in the loss of the 40 bps of margin benefit achieved as a result of the MIP Programme in the first half of this year, and the majority of the 90 bps delivered in 2016.

PM11:27am

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Quoting Mark 8:25

PM11:53am

(Look, I'm a Murphy)

PM11:53am

In our view, Aldermore's shares have been grotesquely undervalued for the past year. As such, despite rising 40% in 3 weeks, (+190% in 15 months), we only regard the 313p indicative offer from FirstRand (Hold) as reasonable; certainly not over-generous. That said, mispriced shares have to correct somehow - OneSavings (Buy) and Virgin Money (Buy) - you're the next!

11:53 am
PM11:54am

Ian of Investec really does like the Challengers

PM11:54am

From a FirstRand perspective, we see the attraction. (1) it stands to acquire what we see as an attractive, low-risk (buy-to-let-led) business at an undemanding valuation (9.6x 2017e EPS) with an outstanding outlook for sustained rapid growth as, de facto, a "free option", (2) its ownership of MotoNovo, with a UK vehicle asset finance book of c.£3bn, should offer some synergies with ALD’s more diversified asset finance unit, (3) then there is ALD’s funding machine...

PM11:54am

We think ALD's attractive funding franchise is a key attraction (which also seemingly “comes for free”). As discussed in our report, UK Banking's best kept secret? (2 Oct), it had built up material excess liquidity at 30 June, with strong deposit growth from its retail/SME franchises as well as Term Funding Scheme drawings of £0.9bn. Moreover, ALD's average cost of funds has fallen by 0.85% through H1 2014-H1 2017 and will fall further in H2 2017e. FirstRand may see ALD's liquidity surplus, augmented by further TFS drawings and strong deposit generation as attractive in the context of MotoNovo's funding requirements too.

11:54 am
PM11:55am

Through the eyes of Aldermore's shareholders, the share price correction is clearly welcome. We think the indicative offer might be considered "reasonable", albeit it most certainly falls short of our view of the value that an independent, low-risk, Aldermore should generate over the medium-term.

We raise our TP to 313p (from 300p) to match the indicative proposal, and with more limited residual upside implied, we reluctantly downgrade to Hold (from Buy). We advise investors to recycle profits into OneSavings and Virgin Money.
